BACKGROUND 1.1 Mexico is unique in that between 70 and 80 percent of its 55 million hectares of forest are under communal ownership by 8,000 forest ejidos and indigenous communities. This unusually extensive communal ownership of Mexico's forests poses important challenges for the sustainable development and conservation of forestry resources. The Government has taken steps in the last five years to remove distortions in the policy framework that were negatively affecting the forestry sector, and to put in place streamlined institutional mechanisms to support the development of the sector. FORESTRY RESOURCES 1.2 Forests and wildlands cover 72 percent of Mexico's territory. Forests in Mexico fall into the following major categories: temperate coniferous and broadleafed; tropical evergreen, semi-evergreen and deciduous; arid and semiarid; and wetlands. The temperate and tropical forests cover 55 million hectares, or 25 percent of Mexico's territory. Sixty percent (31.8 million hectares) are classified as temperate, of which two-thirds are mixed coniferous forests, and the rest broadleafed or cloud forests. The mixed coniferous forests are distributed along the most important mountain ranges of the Sierra Madre Oriental, Sierra Madre Occidental, Sierra Madre del Sur, and Eje Neovolcanico, and are mainly concentrated in the states of Chihuahua, Durango, Michoacan, Jalisco, Guerrero, and Oaxaca. 1.3 Tropical forests include tropical evergreen and serni-evergreen forests (5.8 million hectares), of which eighty percent are located in the states of Campeche, Chiapas, Oaxaca, Quintana Roo, and Veracruz. Tropical deciduous forests (11 million hectares) occur mainly in the coastal plains of the Pacific Coast, the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, and the north of the Yucatan Peninsula. There are also small areas of mangrove stands scattered along the Gulf of Mexico and the Pacific Coasts. Arid and semiarid areas are scattered throughout the northern and central states. 1.4 Based on slope, quality of resource and legal zoning status, 21 million hectares of forest have been identified as having potential for sustainable productive use for
 2 commercial timber. Of this total, only 7 million hectares are under management. These forests and wildlands hold an extraordinary richness of flora and fauna in diverse ecosystems over a wide range of altitudes and rainfall patterns. 1.5 Over the past five decades, wildlands have declined considerably. Traditional systems of shifting cultivation, which in some cases are unsustainable, can be the basis of long term management. However, there is clear evidence that the continued deforestation, estimated recently at 620,000 to 680,000 hectares per year, is resulting in conversion of forest lands to less productive uses with negative environmental externalities. As documented in the Mexico Resource Conservation and Forestry Sector Review (Grey Cover Report No. 13114-ME, March 31, 1995), the resource base is also underutilized and degraded. 1.6 Environmental and social values and the commercial potential of non-traditional products have been largely ignored, even though these combined values greatly exceed timber and alternative use values alone. Data is available on the production of traditionally traded non-timber and non-traditional forest products (NTFPs), such as chicle, mushrooms, resin, orchids, asparagus, edible palms, peppers, gladioli bulbs, yuca, nopal, oregano, heno, nogal, honey and oak products, but data is not available on non-traditional NTFPs. Examples of these include traditional medicines, herbs, edible fruits and seeds, flavorings, fibers, dyes, essences, fragrances, and insects. The recorded production of NTFPs is highest in the temperate forests (38,000 tons per annum), followed by output in the arid/semiarid formations (17,500 tons per annum), and the tropical moist formations (12,800 tons per annum). 1.7 The state of Oaxaca covers 9.5 million hectares (4.8 percent of national territory) in southern Mexico and is bordered by the states of Veracruz and Puebla to the north- northeast, Chiapas to the east, Guerrero to the west, and the Pacific Ocean to the south. Two of Mexico's principal mountain ranges, the Sierra Madre del Sur and Sierra Madre Oriental, meet in Oaxaca, creating a unique geography of temperate mountain terrain juxtaposed with tropical vegetation as well as more temperate coastlands. Oaxaca' s vegetation ranges from desert brush to temperate pines, to humid jungle and mangroves. 1.8 Forests and other natural vegetation cover 7.1 million hectares of Oaxaca (74 percent of state territory). About five million hectares (72 percent of state forest cover) are made up of temperate and tropical forests, which represent 9 percent of the national forest cover, and makes Oaxaca the state with the third highest quantity of forests. Temperate forests, primarily pine and oak, cover 2.7 million hectares of Oaxaca and represent 53 percent of state forest cover. Tropical forests cover 2.4 million hectares, representing 47 percent of state forest cover. In addition, Oaxaca has 28,000 hectares of arid brush and related cover, and 2,300 hectares of wetlands. The state has 1.9 million hectares (27 percent of state forest cover) of degraded forest, which includes semi- forested areas encroached upon by farming, grazing, timber extraction, and forest fires.
 3 1.9 Besides Oaxaca, the other five priority states with pine-oak forests are Chihuahua, Durango, Jalisco, Michoacan, and Guerrero. These five states comprise about 57 rnillion hectares (29 percent of Mexico's land area) and have extensive pine-oak and other forest resources. The combined area of temperate (mostly pine-oak) forest in these five states is about 17.5 million hectares (31 percent of these states' land area). Chihuahua has the most extensive temperate forests (about 7 million hectares), followed by Durango (about 5 million hectares), Jalisco and Guerrero (about 2 million hectares each), and Michoacan (1.5 million hectares). These five states also contain approximately 4.8 million hectares of tropical dry and moist forests, as well as about 12.7 nillion hectares of other natural ecosystems (including grasslands, deserts, and wetlands). Taken together, natural ecosystems (excluding converted or highly degraded areas) still cover approximately 69 percent of Durango; 68 percent of Chihuahua; 55 percent of Guerrero; 48 percent of Michoacan; and 44 percent of Jalisco. COMMUNITY MANAGEMENT OF FORESTRY RESOURCES 1.10 Article 27 of the 1917 Constitution defines three basic categories of land rights: ejido, communal property, and small private property. Ejidos constitute a land grant for usufruct to a population group, and until the constitutional reforms of 1992, ejido land essentially belonged to the state and could not be sold. Communal property is based on the historical rights of pre-Hispanic indigenous communities who have maintained their traditional communal property structure. Small private property is privately owned and is subject to size limits according to the quality of the land and type of crop or economic activity. 1.11 Over 8,000 communities and ejidos throughout the country have forestry resources within their boundaries, and about 5,000 of these exploit their forests commercially. Other communities and ejidos use their forests as a source of fuelwood, medicinal plants, foodstuffs, household construction materials and utensils, and frames and posts for agricultural use. Forests have an important present and potential role to play for these communities and ejidos: (a) commercially as a source of timber and non-timber products for domestic consumption or export; (b) as the source of a range of subsistence and informally-marketed products; (c) as religious and cultural sacred sites of the different indigenous, ethnic groups in forested areas; and (d) as a resource base for tourism and recreational enterprises benefiting these communities and ejidos. 1.12 Communities have been given more recognition as legitimate local governments. Some communities have begun to prepare communal statutes that formalize customary law agreements regarding political organization, social values, land boundaries and tenure, natural resource management, and identification of sacred sites. These statutes could serve as a vehicle for formally recording aspects of the forest management plans relevant to cultural values. Most commercial resource allocation decisions revolve around timber extraction. A few communities are involved seasonally in the lucrative white mushroom trade, but other foodstuffs and medicinal plants are at present low volume, low market value products.
 4 1.13 Of the 1,300 to 1,500 communities and ejidos in Oaxaca, an estimated 40 percent have temperate forest holding within their boundaries, and 228 communities and eight ejidos have significant pine-oak forest areas within their boundaries large enough to warrant commercial exploitation (ranging from 500 to 20,000 hectares and averaging about 5,000 hectares per community). 1.14 There is strong ethnic and cultural diversity among the 236 communities and ejidos with pine-oak forest in Oaxaca, which come from six of Oaxaca's 16 ethnicities, namely the Zapoteca, Mixteca, Nahuatl, Cuicateco, Chinanteca, and Mixe. Some of the common characteristics of these communities and ejidos include: (a) strong cultural values regarding forest resources; (b) strong values for allocating a share of forest profits to social goods and employment; (c) existence of sacred sites within communal forest areas; (d) preference for employing community members as technical forest advisors to ensure cultural values are reflected in forest management; and (e) an independent social and cultural identity of individual communities vis-a-vis other communities, even those of the same general ethnic group. There is wide variation in the extent to which a broad group of community and ejido members participate in forestry decisions. Women, in general, do not participate in the forestry sector, although they are involved in fuelwood and non- timber product collection. Only in the more diversified forestry enterprises have women found roles in accounting and administrative duties. Some of the more developed enterprises employ community members as technical forest advisors. 1.15 Of these 236 communities and ejidos with significant pine-oak forest areas within their boundaries, 114 manage 550,000 hectares of pine-oak forests (only 20 percent of the state's total pine-oak forests) and have management plans, with 41 selling standing timber, 43 harvesting timber, and 30 harvesting and processing timber in their own mills. Ten communities are organized into inter-community unions with integrated forest enterprises. The other communities and ejidos have important forestry resources, but do not manage any commercial timber extraction. 1.16 Oaxaca is one of the poorest states in Mexico, with annual per capita income of 40 percent of the national average, and in Oaxaca the indigenous communities are among the poorest. Land and agricultural policies, combined with high poverty levels in the communities and ejidos of Oaxaca exert strong pressure to expand agricultural production to forested areas. At the same time, the high levels of out-migration in search ofjobs has reduced the pressure on the resource base, and has resulted in some agricultural areas remaining fallow. On balance, the rate of deforestation in Oaxaca seems to be decreasing. 1.17 In the pine-oak forests of Oaxaca, the timber stand in 1994 represented 135.6 million cubic meters, with an annual increment of 1.9 million cubic meters. In that year cutting permits were authorized for 1.1 million cubic meters, with actual extraction of 0.4 million cubic meters. This extraction is only 23 percent of the annual increment, 38 percent of the authorized cut, and about two-thirds of the processing capacity in the state. Clearly there is vast potential for increased sustainable timber extraction in Oaxaca.
 5 1.18 Access by communities to information and technical assistance on forestry issues is limited. In recent years, most government-financed technical assistance for forestry has been privatized. Many of the government employees have fulfilled the education and experience requirements to work as private providers of forestry services, and have registered in the national forestry registry, the Registro Nacional Forestal. These private providers provide a range of forestry services, including the preparation of forestry management plans, annual cutting plans, and tree markings. There are at present no registration requirements for the provision of other technical services to forest resource owners, such as forest product processing, accounting, marketing, and environmental assessments. 1.19 About half of the pine-oak area under management in Oaxaca has benefited from the assistance of 6 companies and 17 individuals registered as private providers of forestry services, as well as unregistered private providers of non-forestry services and community forestry specialists. Private providers have traditionally been paid as a percentage of the extracted timber, and communities indicate that their use of private provider services is limited by the number of private providers, and the range of services they provide, rather than by cash flow constraints. While some of the private providers are able to provide high quality advisory services, their skills need substantial upgrading, and their services need closer monitoring by the communities and forestry institutions. 1.20 There is strong potential for communities and ejidos to improve their market niche. Markets for wood for the construction industry have been restricted due to the economic downturn starting in December 1994, although the devaluation of the peso has given Mexican wood a price advantage over imported wood. The limited access of communities and ejidos to diverse markets is related to a number of factors: the high cost of transport due to lack of road infrastructure; the inability of forestry enterprises to supply wood of a given quality and quantity on a timely basis; the lack of working capital for harvesting and processing; and the lack of technical knowledge. Most communities are selling high quality pine into an undifferentiated market, even though there is strong domestic and international demand for higher value products. Cash flow for harvesters is also uncertain, since many of the smaller processing industries that buy wood from communities have their own marketing problems and are often unable to pay on time. POLICY FRAMEWORK Land Tenure and Agricultural Policies 1.21 Land tenure policies have generally had a negative impact on the forests in Mexico. The process for allocating land and resource rights has had far-reaching implications for efficiency in land and resource management. Parceling gave the ejido member exclusive use of an area of land. However, in order to maintain the right to use the land, the ejidatario had to work his land. Legally, the ejidatario could not rent, lease, or sell his land nor hire others to work it. In practice, informal land markets existed in
 6 many ejidos but ejido land is undervalued relative to private holdings. In Oaxaca, where there is a high concentration of indigenous communities and only a few forestry ejidos, the incentive to clear forest to create parcels has been lower. 1.22 The Agrarian Reform of 1934, which operationalized Article 27 of the Constitution, promoted the occupation and clearing of forest lands. By legally focusing on agricultural parcels, it ignored forest lands, thus giving open access to those who could in fact convert land to an agricultural or livestock use, a precondition for obtaining a parcel. This, combined with the forest concession policies, was a main force underlying the high deforestation rates that started in the 1940s, while preventing the privatization of forests. The Constitutional Reform of 1947 also followed this pattern. For example, forest lands were not included in the complex system of land distribution and demarcation, and the overall result of the lack of policies on forest preservation was a run on forested lands and the advance of the agricultural frontier. 1.23 Oaxacan forests were seriously affected by the Agrarian Reform of 1934 and the Constitutional Reform of 1947, where land that was either indigenous or nominally state- owned was claimed as private land. Such land claims were most common in broadleaf forests, but also occurred in pine-oak forests. Because these laws focused exclusively on agricultural land, rural residents were encouraged to convert land to agricultural or livestock use to establish recognizable claims. 1.24 Rapid growth in the agricultural sector in the late 1940s through the mid-1960s encouraged forest conversion. During this time the agricultural sector grew more than 4 percent a year, outstripping population growth and surpassing any other Latin American country. By 1965, most of the better quality land was under cultivation and productivity per hectare showed no further improvement. The cumulative result was that between 1965 and 1980, agricultural Gross Domestic Product grew only at 2.4 percent per year, slower than population growth. Demand for grains surpassed production capacity and Mexico became a net importer of grains. The livestock sector expanded mainly between 1972 and 1985. The number of beef cattle grew by 15 percent, matching growth in consumption which was 16 percent. The area devoted to fodder production also increased by more than 100 percent between 1970 and 1985. 1.25 Direct and indirect subsidies to stimulate production included direct investment in the agriculture and livestock sector, producer subsidies, and promotion of production activities through parastatals. An extensive network of subsidies developed supporting: fertilizers, pesticides, fuel, electricity, credit, water, seeds, and crop insurance. The Farm Support Payments Program (Programa de Apoyos Directos al Campo; PROCAMPO) was initiated in 1994 to assist farmers to move to more profitable land uses by channeling a limited-term payment on a parcel basis to farmers formerly qualifying for crop subsidies. In states like Oaxaca, however, where records are imperfect, farmers had incentives to clear new parcels, some in forested areas, in order to become eligible for limited-term payments on these parcels.
 7 1.26 The reform of Article 27 of the Constitution in 1992 introduced fundamental changes in land rights: land redistribution was eliminated, transactions of ejido lands were authorized, ejido farmers were given the right to sell their lands, and agrarian courts were created to solve land claim conflicts. With the new law, an ejido can decide to distribute agricultural land parcels to its members under full private ownership or to continue with the present system. However, in common-use lands, where most of the forests are found, land cannot be parceled or sold. An explicit objective of the reform is to create a climate for more sustainable common resource management, encouraging ejido members to rationalize forest management and use. Under the reform, they are also encouraged to seek joint ventures with private investors, with the certainty that their rights over the common-use lands are secure. This lays the groundwork to avoid the open access problems of the past. Forestry Policies 1.27 Forestry policies have attempted to exert a countervailing force to land reform and agricultural and economic policies, with partial success. Mexico has had forestry legislation since 1884, but in practice this has often been overridden by other policies. Most of the legislation has been heavy on regulation and de facto control, limiting the users' decision making power over the resource. Regulations imposed costs on forest users and added to the incentives for conversion of forests to agricultural land. 1.28 The 1884 Regulations were oriented mainly to the regulation of levels of commercial harvesting, with the objective of sustaining yields through a complex system of land classification and use regulations. In the late 1800s, concessions were opened to large (primarily U.S.) lumber firms, mostly in the northern areas of Mexico's pine-oak forests. At the turn of the century and just before the Mexican Revolution, these firms were expropriated and their mills turned over to national owners, who since then have generally faced problems due to lack of sufficient timber supply and inefficient administration. One legacy of this period is the continued location of most timber processing plants away from the resource, near centers of consumption. In part, this was the result of the extensiveness of extraction (once one source of supply was logged out, the industry shifted extraction to another more distant location) and the desire to avoid labor problems associated with drawing upon the same labor pool for extraction and processing. Now that industry supplies are more limited than before, the transport costs for the processing centers in the north are quite high relative to the available source of raw material. In Oaxaca, with the exception of some remote communities in the southern part of the state, distances from communities to potential buyers are much shorter, and high costs are related to inefficiencies in harvesting, processing and transport. 1.29 After the 1910 revolution, the forests of Mexico were largely transferred to ejidos and indigenous communities, although the process was slow and continued well into the 1970s. In 1926, the first Forest Law was introduced with a focus on conservation. This law was progressively conservationist for its time, but was largely neutralized by the land
 8 reform that channeled public resources toward crop and livestock production and favored land allocation to those without forest cover or standing trees on their holdings. 1.30 The legal passing of actual control of the forest resources to the ejidos and communities was only possible with the 1942 Forestry Law, and even then government control and interference continued to be heavy, including the establishment of parastatals that essentially had monopoly power over management and harvesting of the forests. Large haciendas and their forests were expropriated and, while ownership rights were legally retained by the federal government, usufruct rights to the trees and land resource were turned over to ejidos and communities. At the same time, private forest products manufacturing firms were prohibited from owning forest lands, which effectively left them dependent on ejido and community suppliers, as well as the small private landowners. The main parastatal established during this period in Oaxaca was the Fabricas de Papel Tuxtepec (FAPATUX), a pulp factory. 1.31 The 1986 Forestry Law introduced much greater environmental regulation within the context of the management plans, and gave the Government a stronger role in plan approval and monitoring. The 1986 Forestry Law continued the spirit of heavy state intervention initiated in the 1942 Forestry Law through management plans, and cutting, transport, processing, and selling permits. This intervention was justified by the view that, left to their own, communities would not be able to manage their forests in the public interest. The law also restricted any change of land use in fragile lands or public forests and reserves. The 1986 Forestry Law did not include technical norms in its regulations, which helped create a high level of insecurity among forest resource owners regarding their legal rights. 1.32 The policies related to forestry deprived the private sector of a resource base and created a three way split of the sector: the communities and ejidos held most utilization rights to the resource; the public sector maintained control of the resource and hence had the power to legislate and, theoretically at least, to regulate the management of the resource and administration of the sector as a whole; and the private sector housed most of the industry. This arrangement, coupled with poorly implemented intervention by government regulatory agencies, virtually guaranteed the conflict and distrust that effectively crippled the sector and still limits relations today. It placed most of the country's forest resources in the hands of poor, unskilled farmers, but failed to provide the needed resources for proper management. In Oaxaca, the main communities supplying FAPATUX effectively blocked renewal of the concession to this parastatal. This fight gave them political will for some to form their own processing unions. 1.33 Mexico passed a new Forestry Law in 1992 and the implementing regulations were issued in 1994. This was a sweeping revision of previous legislation and had as its main objectives the transformation of government forestry agencies from executors and direct interventionists into more normative organizations. As such, the new law eliminated many executive responsibilities and allowed for decentralization to state level agencies. The major change was the transfer of forest management, conservation, protection and
 9 improvement responsibilities to the forest land owners and producers, leaving the Government with a normative and supervisory role. Federal agencies would no longer provide direct technical assistance services to the forest owners and producers, or be directly involved in the transportation, warehousing or manufacturing of forest products. As part of these legal changes, the Government sold off any remaining parastatal forest products firms. 1.34 In March 1996, Mexican President Zedillo announced the Forestry Program for 1995 to 2000, with the dual objectives of conservation and protection of forestry resources, and the increase of forestry's contribution to the Gross Domestic Product. The conservation and protection program includes: prevention of forest fires; disease prevention and control; technical assistance to forestry communities; special plantations and production of charcoal; increased inspection; and decentralized permitting procedures. The program to increase productivity includes: the establishment of a Fund to provide seed money for road building, payments to private providers of forestry services, integrated production, and diversified use of the forestry resources including non-timber products, and restoration of critical areas; credit and financing programs with different government institutions, development banks, and agencies, to stimulate the sector; training and technical assistance for communities and industries; and development of a market information system. FORESTRY INSTITUTIONS 1.35 As part of the consolidation of environmental activities under the Zedillo administration, responsibility for forestry activities was shifted from the Secretariat of Agriculture and Rural Development (Secretaria de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural; SAGAR) to the Secretariat of Environment, Natural Resources, and Fisheries (Secretaria de Medio Ambiente, Recursos Naturales y Pesca; SEMARNAP). Within SEMARNAP, several agencies have responsibility for forestry related activities. The Forestry Department (Direccion General Forestal; DGF) within the Sub-Secretariat of Natural Resources has primary responsibility for forest utilization and management, forest protection, forest development, and commercial reforestation. The Forest Utilization Division within DGF (Direccion de Aprovechaniiento Forestal; DAF), is in charge of forest utilization and management. The National Forestry Council (Consejo Tecnico Consultivo Nacional Forestal; CONAF) serves as the interface between the Government, private sector, academics, and non-governmental organizations. The Tropical Forestry Action Plan Program (Programa de Accion Forestal Tropical; PROAFT) funds activities in tropical forests. The Department of Soil Conservation and Restoration (Direccion General de Conservacion y Restauracion de Suelos) carries out land use planning activities that include forested areas and watersheds. The Sub-Secretariat of Planning assists the Sub-Secretariat of Natural Resources with forestry policies and plans.

The National Ecology Institute (Instituto Nacional de Ecologia; INE) is responsible for the review and approval of the environmental impact aspects of forestry management programs for both commercial forests and natural protected areas, an activity which is carried out by the agency at state level. The Environmental Protection Agency (Procuraduria Federal de Proteccion al Ambiente; PFPA) is responsible for enforcing compliance with the forestry management plans, an activity which is carried out by the agency at state level, and audited at the federal level. The National Biodiversity Commission (Comision Nacional de Aprovechamiento de la Biodiversidad; CONABIO) is responsible for biodiversity uses and products. 1.37 In line with other Government Secretariats, SEMARNAP is planning the general deconcentration and decentralization of its activities. The current stage is the strengthening of the state level institutions and the deconcentration of activities and resources from SEMARNAP in Mexico City to the SEMARNAP state delegations. The lessons learned from this project include the following: (a) Inadequate environmental and social guidelines at the Bank and in Mexico resulted in a three year delay in project implementation due to conditionality regarding an environmental baseline study. Since then, the Government has enacted the Forestry Law of 1992 and its associated regulations. At the Bank, Operational Directives have been issued on environmental topics, but not on Participation Plans. (b) An adequate social assessment and plan for stakeholder participation was not carried out during preparation, hampering the dialogue with communities, and
 12 local and international non-governmental organizations. The Community Forestry Project has carried out a full social assessment at the national level, and at the state level in Oaxaca, and discussions have been held with non-governmental organizations based in Oaxaca and Mexico City. (c) Lack of state government participation and commitment to the project hampered project implementation. The Community Forestry Project has had strong support from the Governor of Oaxaca, who has established a State Coordinating Commission for the project with representatives of the most relevant state level Secretariats. (d) Even though the administration changed between project appraisal and negotiations, the project was not reappraised, leading to a lack of ownership, and inadequate project implementation procedures. (e) The project never received adequate budgetary resources. The Community Forestry Project has already been assigned a budget for retroactive financing and for the first year of project implementation, and there is strong commitment to continue providing budgetary support. 1.43 Recognizing the complexity of the sector and its need for a more clearly defined strategy, the Government requested Bank assistance to carry out a sector study, finalized as the Mexico Resource Conservation and Forestry Sector Review (Grey Cover Report No. 131 14-ME; March 31, 1995). This joint effort identified several key constraints to the development of the forestry sector, including: (a) lack of adequate transport and production infrastructure; (b) lack of information on business opportunities, markets, and technologies; (c) lack of timely credit on appropriate terms; (c) undifferentiated product markets and price volatility; (d) uncertainty regarding land tenure and boundary demarcations; (e) underutilization of non-timber and non-traditional forest resources; (f) poorly trained community and ejido resource managers and workers; and (g) the loss of resources as a result of deforestation and the loss of biodiversity. The sector study has shown that forestry has a much greater economic potential than is being realized, a large share of which could reach the poorest communities and ejidos. 1.44 Based on this analysis of constraints and economic potential, a strategy has been developed for the sector on which the Government and the Bank agree. The Government has already announced its strategy for the sector, and has requested Bank support for this pilot operation that could lead to similar operations in the other five states with pine-oak forests. This project builds on prior experience, sector work, and other work such as the ejido-to-ejido training supported by the Institutional Development Fund Grant (IDF Grant; Grant Number TF 28855), and continuing dialogue and consultation with stakeholders in the sector.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION BACKGROUND Origin 2.1 This proposed project was prepared based on the recommendations of a workshop held to discuss the findings of the Grey Cover Mexico Resource Conservation and Forest Sector Review (Report No. 13114-ME; March 31, 1995). At that workshop representatives of the federal government, state governments, communities, ejidos, non- governmental organizations, academics, and others gathered to discuss the recommendations presented in the Sector Review, and agree on next steps. The workshop confirmed the need for a pilot operation to provide technical assistance and training to the communities, to strengthen the private sector providers of services, to enhance opportunities for testing the potential of non-timber and non-traditional forest products, as well as strengthening Government approval and monitoring functions. 2.2 Oaxaca was selected as an appropriate site for this pilot operation due to: strong and well organized forestry communities and ejidos which own 90 percent of the forestry resources within the state; important forestry resources within the state, including pine- oak forests with commercial potential; high biodiversity within the forestry areas under community management, that could benefit from protection; experience by communities with private providers of forestry services, which could be further developed; successful sustainable use of some non-timber forest products such as white mushrooms; and strong support from the Governor of Oaxaca. Objectives 2.3 The overall objective of the project is to support the implementation of key elements in the Government's redefined natural resource management strategy. Specific objectives of the project are to: (a) improve natural resource management and conservation by community and ejido forestry resource owners; and (b) increase the range of forestry-based income generating options available to them. To this end, the project would (a) strengthen the capacity of communities and ejidos to manage their forest resource base; (b) strengthen the capacity of the private sector to provide forestry services to communities and ejidos; (c) design strategies to promote timber, non-timber, and non- traditional products from community and ejido forests; and (d) strengthen the federal and state institutions working in forestry conservation and development.

Technical assistance is tailored to the needs of the four categories of forestry communities and ejidos: (a) 122 communities with no management plans and no commercial extraction; (b) 41 communities that sell standing timber, but do not harvest the timber themselves; (c) 43 communities that harvest and sell cut timber, but have no processing capacity; and (d) 30 communities with harvesting and processing enterprises, including communities that are grouped into forestry unions. This component has three sub-components: (a) Promotional Activities. This subcomponent would finance communications specialists, non-governmental organizations, consultants, salaries, equipment, workshops, and promotional materials, including video and radio, to inform potential participants about the scope of the available assistance, carry out 175 participatory rapid appraisals, promote regional fora for community participation, and evaluate the needs and interests of participants in order to better design training programs and future activities. (b) Technical Assistance. This sub-component would finance part of the costs of the technical assistance provided by private providers under contracts with participating communities and ejidos. Topics would be deterrnined by the communities and ejidos, based on eligibility criteria, and could include: management plans for timber extraction based on regenerative capacity; conservation plans for forested areas; integrated resource management and forestry research; and forest enterprise efficiency.  21 JUSTIFICATION Rationale for Project Design 2.13 The project has been designed to empower the communities and ejidos in their decision making as to the nature, extent, and timing of the training and technical assistance on sustainable forestry management they would receive. Private providers of technical assistance will be hired by the communities through community procurement procedures. To improve the skills of these private providers, training is being provided through the project. To enable communities to make full use of their forestry resources, the project would promote NTFPs as an alternative to traditional timber products. Existing institutions that are involved in the regulation or enforcement of the forestry sector are being strengthened. Activities that are clearly related to the existence of a Bank financed project are being handled by Project Management and Project Implementation Units at the federal and state level. A detailed monitoring and evaluation system is included, given the pilot nature of the activities in Oaxaca, and the Government's intention of replicating the successes of the pilot in the five other priority states with pine-oak forest. Rationale for Bank Involvement 2.14 The proposed project would provide strong support to the Government's strategy for the forestry sector. It would strengthen environmental management, address issues of income generation in some of the poorest indigenous communities in the south of Mexico, and would support the process of administrative decentralization, all priorities in the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy for Mexico (Report No. 16056-ME; October 15, 1996), and would complement ongoing environmental and poverty-focused operations in Mexico. As a pilot project, it would provide a unique opportunity to learn valuable lessons on how to work with communities to undertake natural resource management activities. Program Objective Categories 2.15 The proportion of the poor among project beneficiaries is expected to be significantly larger than their proportion in the overall population, therefore this project fits the criteria for inclusion in the Program of Targeted Interventions. The project belongs primarily to the Environmentally Sustainable Development and Poverty Reduction and Human Resource Development program objective categories. Given its focus on communities and ejidos, and on private service providers, the project also belongs to the Private Sector Development program objective category.

PROJECT ANALYSIS SOCIAL ANALYSIS 4.1 Project preparation has included a lengthy process of social assessment and participation plan preparation, including a special emphasis on indigenous development, given that more than 90 percent of the targeted beneficiaries belong to indigenous ethnicities. The social assessment included: (a) country-level sector analysis, with field data collection and focus-group interviews; (b) a gender study, with field survey data and secondary literature review; (c) an indigenous peoples' assessment as a background study within the country-level sector analysis, plus follow-up focus-group interviews in the state of Oaxaca; (d) recommendations from community-to-community training workshops, carried out as an IDF indigenous training initiative; and (e) social assessment of the four categories of forestry communities and ejidos, drawing on community, government, and non-governmental organization interviews and workshops. 4.2 This analysis identified a clear opportunity to involve indigenous forest communities and ejidos in improved forest management and forest enterprises. As a result of the social analysis, the technical assistance and training support is tailored to different levels of community organization, includes the possibility of using community forestry technicians as private providers, allows for exchange of experiences between more sophisticated and less sophisticated forest communities, and incorporates space for cultural values and customary tenure arrangements. The project will include a promotional campaign channeled in part through regional gatherings of communities, devolving responsibility for these gatherings to community leaders over time. In addition, training will be tailored to specific community needs, and courses will be held locally as much as possible to encourage busy household heads to attend. The success of project activities will be measured through participatory monitoring and evaluation as well as by external evaluation of development objectives and performance indicators. ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS 4.3 The project has been given a Category B rating. It is expected to have a positive impact on the sustainable management of forestry resources at the community and ejido level by: (a) providing technical assistance to local people in the conservation and management of their forestry resources; and (b) ensuring the compatibility of forest management with the supply of important non-timber forest products and environmental benefits; and (c) discouraging the conversion of forests to croplands or pastures as a result of promoting better forest management practices. Because of the nature and small size of
 33 the physical investments financed under the grants component of the proejct, no resettlement is expected or even plausible. 4.4 The project could have a potentially negative environmental impact as a result of: (a) the decentralization of government programs for conservation and management to state and local levels, involving weak institutions; (b) unsustainable management practices for forests and wildiands being managed for varied uses, including supply of non-timber forest products, for which management experience is still relatively new; and (c) the intensification of pine-oak forest management resulting in ecological degradation of these natural habitats. The project contains multiple environmental safeguards, intended to ensure that project-promoted forest management activities would not cause significant damage to biodiversity, soils, or water quality. As detailed in SEMARNAP's Environmental Analysis (Conservacion y Manejo Sustentable de Recursos Forestales en Mexico: Analisis Ambiental; October 1996), these safeguards include the promotion of forest conservation plans, environmental training and technical assistance to communities and private service providers, a biodiversity advisor, environmental institutional strengthening, forestry research, and environmental project monitoring. ECONOMIC AND FISCAL ANALYSIS 4.5 There is strong economic justification for this project, as discussed throughout this report: the project concept and design is coherently set in the economic and sector work that proceeded it, and fits within the country assistance strategy; the project targets indigenous communities in one of the poorest states in Mexico; the project design is optimal given the constraints in the sector; technical, environmental, and institutional risks have been carefully evaluated, and actions have been included in the project to reduce these risks; and indicators have been devised to monitor project performance. 4.6 The Government of Mexico has justified the fiscal outlays associated with this project for social and environrnental reasons, given that the indigenous communities in Oaxaca are among the poorest in Mexico, and that their successful management of their forestry resources could increase the range of income-generating options available to these communities. At the same time, better management could result in higher value added production, more employment in the rural sector, less imports of timber products, and perhaps even exports of non-timber products, all of which would generate a positive revenue flow through taxation. Communities and ejidos in Oaxaca are known to channel surplus resources into community goods such as water supply, drainage, primary education, scholarships, and health services. Any increase in revenues at the community level, and substitution for publicly provided goods, would reduce the fiscal burden on the Government. PROJECT BENEFITS 4.7 The project would empower communities and ejidos in Oaxaca to improve their management of forestry resources, and to increase the range of income generating options
 34 available to them. It would do so by: closing the knowledge gap through training; improving the quality and increasing the range of advisory services available to communities through private providers of technical assistance; developing options for NTFPs; and improving the services provided to the communities by Government institutions. The project would operationalize innovative thinking in Mexico and elsewhere on the best ways to assist indigenous owners of communal property in sustainable management of their resource base. If successful, the project would provide a model that could be replicated in other indigenous communities that are willing to undertake sustainable natural resource management activities. 4.8 Project benefits are concentrated on poor and indigenous families in Oaxaca. Ninety percent of the target population is indigenous and forested areas covered by the project are all within municipalities defined as poor and marginal. Oaxacan communities make a concerted effort to distribute employment and training opportunities widely, and to channel surplus resources into community goods. In addition, community forest development plans in the more organized communities reflect a cultural value on investments of forest income in activities that generate diversity of production and therefore increase employment. The experience in some communities suggests that as sustainable management of the resource increases, communities can increase harvesting, invest in improved and more diversified processing, and over the medium-term begin to invest in other employment-generating, timber or non-timber cash crop activities. PROJECT RISKS 4.9 Following on the heels of the unsuccessful Mexico Forestry Development Project, this project could receive unusually high scrutiny and residual criticism. External factors could significantly reduce the prospects for the forestry sector in Mexico: the implementation of the current PROCAMPO program favors the short term conversion of forestry lands to agriculture; trade with North America has increased the availability of lower cost, higher quality, forestry products in the main markets in Mexico; population growth may increase pressure to convert forested areas to agriculture; and credit for forestry activities is not always available on a timely basis. Project objectives are limited and appropriate, and would enable communities to improve the long term productivity of their resource base. 4.10 The project poses other significant risks. The most important of these is that the major project components are demand driven, and although consultations with communities and private providers have indicated a high level of demand, there is substantial risk of failure as a result of lack of demand. Promotional activities have been designed into the project to increase demand for technical assistance and training on the part of the communities, and to increase awareness and interest on the part of the private providers. Even if there is high demand, it may not be phased according to the assumptions made in the project, leading to slower implementation than is currently expected. Careful management by federal and state agencies is necessary to make
 35 adjustments during implementation. The possibility of revising the project at midterm also allows flexibility in terms of responding to actual demand. 4.11 Also potentially hampering implementation is the weakness of the project agencies at federal and state level. The project is front-loading technical assistance and equipment provided to these agencies in order to mitigate this risk, but this strategy will only be effective if the necessary staff to implement and manage the project are hired on a timely basis, and staff remain in place over the medium term. As with other projects in Mexico, adequate counterpart funding may not be available. While the project has little leverage over the fiscal management systems of the Government, the fact that a budgetary allocation has been made for counterpart funding during preparation for retroactive financing and for the first year of project implementation indicates the priority the Government has placed on this project. 4.12 Project activities pose certain risks. Activities undertaken by communities and ejidos could pose environmental risk; mitigating measures have been included in the project, and would have to be carefully monitored and adjusted as needed. Private providers may not have the technical skills necessary to give the proper advice to communities and ejidos. The private provider registration process and continuing education program, as well as the exclusion of private providers from giving technical assistance on investment decisions, are some of the mechanisms that have been designed to provide a safety net for the communities. The market for non-traditional timber and non-timber forest products is largely unknown and could lead to overexploitation of valuable products or to underutilization of the grant facility. The initial diagnostic studies should prevent any grant funds from being used for overexploited species, rare or endangered species listed in either the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Fauna and Flora or under Mexican regulations as listed in Norma Official Mexicana 059 would be excluded, and the evaluation at midterm would permit an adjustment to the pilot mechanism. SUSTAINABILITY 4.13 The project would finance institutional strengthening activities that are expected to be sustainable in the medium term. In addition, better management of timber resources would result in longer, sustainable extraction of the resource. Commercially viable, environmentally sustainable non-timber and non-traditional timber activities would generate income for their continuation. Demand for the services of private providers is likely to continue in the post-project period as a result of the expected increase in the number of communities managing their forests, and in the intensity of their management. With better training and an improved ability to generate resources for the communities and ejidos, private providers of technical assistance would be able to provide better services to the communities and ejidos, which would also increase the demand for their services.

Background Forestry Technical Assistance in Mexico 2. In the late 1980s government agencies were responsible for providing technical assistance in forestry. However, with the downsizing of federal government budgets in recent years most government-financed technical assistance units (most recently called UCODEFOs) have been privatized. The provision of forest management technical assistance services to forest owners is regulated through Articles 23 and 24 of the Ley Forestal of 1992 and Articles 31 - 37 of Reglamento de la Ley Forestal in 1994. However, this legislation refers only to basic forestry activities including the preparation of forest management programs, harvesting plans and timber marking for felling operations. Persons who wish to provide these technical services must meet a set of minimum qualifications set out under the Forest Regulations and must register themselves with SEMARNAP which records this information in the Registro Nacional Forestal. There are at present no registration requirements for the provision of other technical services to forest land owners such as business practices, accounting, forest product processing, forest product marketing, forest engineering, environmental assessments or related studies. As in other countries, information on the extent, use, production and economic importance of non-timber forest products (NTFPs) in Mexico is incomplete, and what is available is widely dispersed and poorly documented. While reliable data is available on the production of traditionally traded, NTFPs, such as chicle, mushrooms, resin, orchids, asparagus, edible palms, peppers, gladioli bulbs, yuca, nopal, oregano, heno, nogal, honey and opuntia, data on non-traditional informally traded NTFPs is virtually non-existent. Examples of these include traditional medicines, herbs, edible fruits and seeds, flavorings, fibres, dyes, essences, fragrances, and insects. 2. The recorded production of NTFPs is highest in the temperate forests (38,000 tons per annum), followed by output in the arid/semiarid forrnations (17,500 tons per annum), and the tropical moist formations (12,800 tons per annum). However this is not a true reflection of the situation because of poor and incomplete recording, the strong influence which resin production has on output from temperate forests, and the fact that the data does not include non-traded or informally traded NTFPs which are extremely important in some areas. For example, some 350,000 tons of NTFPs such as fruits, rhizomes, roots, flowers and bark are thought to be traded informally each year, and some 1,200 medicinal plants are thought to be in use throughout Mexico. Plants with medicinal potential in Mexico are thought to number about 10,000. Given the unreliability of data, it is difficult to estimate the precise monetary value of NTFP production, but the Mexico Resource Conservation and Forestry Sector Review (Grey Cover Report No. 13114-ME) estimates that the potential annual value of NTFP output could be as high as US$ 7 billion. 3. Concerning management systems for NTFPs, the general picture seems to be one of over-exploitation of a lirnited number of traditional or widely traded products such as chicle, resin, orchids and bushmeat, combined with the under-utilisation of lesser-known products. The negative impact of the mismanagement of NTFPs manifests itself in three ways. The first is one of lost opportunity in that the potential to alleviate rural poverty and improve food security is not being realised. The increased use of NTFPs offers potential to generate much needed income in rural households and to provide valuable dietary supplements at certain times of the year. The second is that the exclusion of NTFPs from forest benefits encourages deforestation because forests become undervalued relative to other land uses. An important contributory factor to forest conversion has always been its undervaluation, whereby the exclusion of values accruing to NTFPs make forests appear to be far less competitive forms of land use than agriculture. In some areas, conversion of forest to agriculture has resulted in serious land degradation and erosion. A better understanding of the role of
 Annex 3 Page 2 of 4 NTFPs could help reverse this process. The third is that the over-exploitation of selected NTFPs may be leading to a loss of biodiversity and environmental degradation. 4. Institutional Responsibility. (a) Review of Forestry Management and Conservation Plans. This sub- component would finance consultants, salaries, field and computer equipment, vehicles, and operating expenditures to strengthen the review, approval, and audit of forestry management and conservation plans by SEMARNAP in Oaxaca. Forestry communities and ejidos are mandated by law to prepare forestry management plans. These plans are prepared by private providers, and cover five to ten years of activity. The plans include information such as location and quantification of the forestry resources, general physical and biological description of the resource base, annual cutting plans describing the species, volumes and expected productivity, description of the silvicultural system, conservation plans, fire prevention and control, environmental impact analysis, reforestation, and infrastructural requirements. In the temperate zone, the inclusion of activities such as road building would require a separate environmental assessment. The benefits that are likely to result from well produced forestry management plans include better forest management which would lead to sustained, increased income flows and improved environmental management and protection. Since 1992, the review and approval of forestry management plans has been delegated to the federal delegations at state level. Since the reorganization of government agencies, these activities now fall to SEMARNAP. Within the SEMARNAP delegation, four units review or audit management plans. The Subdelegation of Natural Resources affiliated with the Direccion General Forestal, is in charge of the process, with inputs from the other units, and issues the 'dictamen' indicating that it has either approved the plan, suggested mitigating measures, or requested more information. The Subdelegation of Environment affiliated with INE, reviews the plan for its environmental impact. The Judicial Unit reviews the plans to make sure the areas covered by the plan are not under dispute since disputed areas are left out of management plans. Once the plans have been approved and the activities have been completed, the PFPA Delegation audits the plan and its implementation, using satellite imagery and reports of the grupos de vigilancia to focus on problem areas. When it encounters problems it imposes fines and sanctions on the private provider and the community, as necessary.
 Annex 4 Page 3 of 5 In 1994 - 1995, 190 forestry management plans for temperate areas were prepared and approved in Oaxaca, covering about 400 cutting permits. About 60 to 70 percent of the forestry management plans are either approved or approved with suggested mitigating measures after the first review. About a dozen were found to have problems after the audit was completed. At present in Oaxaca, the plans are tracked manually, and are often difficult to locate. The reduction in staff as a result of the transfer of responsibilities to SEMARNAP has created bottlenecks and delays in plan review and approval. More staff, with better skills, are needed in the SEMARNAP delegation in Oaxaca. In theory, the findings of the auditors would feed back into the approval process, so that private providers that had been put on probation would not be able to submit plans, and communities that had been fined would be more carefully monitored. In practice, the review and approval process is not linked to the audit process, requiring the creation of a computerized information management system to track each plan, and to link the review, approval, and audit findings. (b) SEMARNAP Delegations and State Secretariats. This sub-component would finance equipment, staff, and operating expenses to strengthen the SEMARNAP delegations and the State Secretariats in the five other priority states with pine-oak forests. SEMARNAP is in the process of planning the deconcentration of resources and responsibilities from the federal level to the state delegations, followed by the decentralization of resources and responsibilities to the State Secretariats. (c) Sistema Nacional de Informacion Forestal (SNIF). This sub-component would finance consultants to design an Internet based system that would enable private producers, academics, non-governmental organizations, government agencies, and others, to access Government information and to create their own databases within the system. An attempt in the previous administration to establish a national information system for the use of government agencies, that would contain government- collected data was aborted with the transfer of responsibilities for forestry from the Secretariat of Agriculture to SEMARNAP. This current proposal is significantly different from the previous proposal in that it reflects the new outlook in the administration towards information sharing with all groups within the society. The SNIF will be an Internet-based system that would enable private producers, academics, non-governmental organizations, government agencies, and others to access the information, and to create their own databases within the system. As part of the SNIF, the Registro Nacional Forestal would be computerized. The Registro is a public register of all the activities that are regulated by the Government. At present, the Registro includes a roster of certified private providers of forestry services, the approved forestry management plans, cutting

The Registro is not computerized, and the data can only be accessed by visiting the office at the Direccion General Forestal in Mexico City, therefore this sub-component would also finance computer hardware and software, terminals at all the state delegations, system administration staff, and maintenance. Applicant Eligibility Only communities and ejidos in the six priority states with pine oak forests, would be eligible to apply; communities would only be eligible to receive assistance for one project; communities should be legally recognised entities with clear and unencumbered title to their forests, and should have an approved management plan for their forests. Proposal Eligibility Forests with disputed ownership or user rights would be excluded; areas subject to total protection would be excluded; project proposals should be financially viable; each proposal should be endorsed by the Comisariado of the community submitting the proposal; only one project per product per state would be financed each year, with a maximum of three projects per product per state; consideration would be given to potentially viable activities adjacent to protected area buffer zones and to the domestication of overexploited species; certain products may be excluded as a result of the studies undertaken in each state in the first year of the project, and will not be eligible. This project is piloting several innovative activities in the forestry sector in Mexico, including demand driven technical assistance and training and grant based non- timber forest product management. If successful, the project would be replicated in other priority states with pine-oak forests. Therefore systematic and accurate reporting and active monitoring is essential to track project performance and make adjustments to project implementation. 2. Six indicators have been selected against which successful implementation would be measured: (a) annual budgetary allocation; (b) increased forest area under improved management; (c) hectares under conservation by communities; (d) number of private providers in the project roster; (e) number of non-timber forest products successfully implemented; and (f) percentage of management plans reviewed within the legally mandated 30 day limit. 3. The Project Management Unit in SEMARNAP in Mexico City would have primary responsibility for project supervision, monitoring and evaluation.
