 Annex 9 Page 1 of 6 MEXICO COMMUNITY FORESTRY PROJECT Social Assessment and Participation Plan Objectives and Scope 1. Project preparation has included a process of social assessment and preparation of a participation plan, with special emphasis on indigenous development given that more than 90 percent of the targeted project beneficiaries belong to indigenous ethnicities. The social assessment includes five stages or elements: (a) a country-level sector analysis for which social issues comprised a significant part of the work/program (Gray Cover "Resource Conservation and Forestry Sector Review," Report No. 13114-ME) and the state of Oaxaca was a case-study site; (b) an indigenous peoples development assessment by a renowned Mexican anthropologist resident in Oaxaca; (c) the recommendations made by 40 indigenous forest ejidos and communities in three ejido-to-ejido training workshops on forestry financed through an Institutional Development Fund Grant; (d) focus group interviews with indigenous forest owners, industrialists, federal and state government forest officials, and private forest technicians; and (e) a series of regional consultations with indigenous ejidos and communities during the pre- evaluation phase. The process aims to: (a) identify social issues important for project design, including the choice of institutional arrangements; (b) collect information regarding felt needs of the target population; (c) identify potential negative social aspects and design mitigating measures to address those impacts; and (d) initiate the process of participation that will be continued during project implementation. A Profile of Project Beneficiaries 2. The project area is coterminous with the temperate forest areas of Oaxaca-- concentrated in the Sierra Norte, Sierra Juarez, Sierra del Sur, and parts of the central valleys. There are between 1300 and 1500 ejidos and indigenous communities in Oaxaca, of which an estimated 40 percent have temperate forest holdings within their boundaries. Estimates are that ejidos total between 700 and 730 and communities between 570 and 750 in number. About 280 ejidos and communities are estimated to have significant temperate and tropical forest holdings large enough to warrant commercial exploitation. The majority of the population (eight ejidos and 228 communities) with temperate forests are indigenous and include six of the sixteen indigenous ethnicity's of Oaxaca, namely the Zapoteca, Mixteca, Nahuatl, Cuicateco, Chinanteca, and Mixe. A significant number of the indigenous population are bilingual speakers of their own language and Spanish, although some communities no longer use their language of origin. Because of the mountainous terrain and limited road networks, some communities are physically isolated and speak distinct dialects that are not readily understood by members of the same ethnic group form other parts of the region. There is a significant degree of poverty and marginality in the municipalities covered by the project.
 Annex 9 Page 2 of 6 3. Political Systems and Local Government. The indigenous groups have maintained their traditional political structures to a large extent. The indigenous communities elect leaders known as Comisariados de Bienes Comunales for a period ranging from one to three years. The communities and ejidos are grouped into 570 municipalities state-wide, some with as few as three communities or ejidos and presided by municipal presidents. Oaxaca underwent municipal elections in November, 1995, and municipal presidents took office in January 1996. In addition to the elected officials, each community has indigenous religious and cultural leaders who are consulted according to traditions of individual ethnic groups. There is a significant migration from Zapoteca and Mixteca to urban centers and the United States, but community members (comuneros) can retain their voting rights. Patterns of Forest Management and Organization for Production 4. There is a wide range of community organization for forestry management and production in the temperate forest areas of the state. There are four categories of forest organizations, based on patterns of forest production: (a) communities that do not have management plans; (b) communities with management plans who do not sell wood; (c) communities with management plans who only sell stumpage; and (d) communities that have some industrial capacity. Some of these latter communities are organized into unions for technical assistance and marketing. These categories are filtered through social characteristics of the communities. Indigenous ejidos and communities place a high value on gaining social as well as economic benefits from their forest management. This has had both positive and negative impacts on organizational efforts. Traditionally, communities make decisions in highly democratic fashion and there is a frequent change of elected leadership to encourage greater rotation of leadership positions. This can be a strength of community forestry, but can also lead to a lack of professionalism in forest resource management, if there is too much rotation of comuneros responsible for managing the community forestry enterprise. The most developed forest communities have sent community youth to be trained in forestry, to return to provide technical services to their community. 5. Social goals are important to many indigenous ejidos. Unlike non-indigenous forest ejidos, indigenous ejidos and communities assign a significant part of the earnings from timber sales to finance social goods, such as schools, feeder roads, health centers, and water supply. There is a range of variation in the importance placed on these goals by different communities. In general, these goals take precedence over long-term investment in the forestry enterprise. Some communities are reluctant to exploit their forest resources for fear of causing ecological damage (seen in a somewhat spiritual sense) and/or for fear of creating social conflicts due to the inability to allocate the earnings in an equitable and socially-acceptable way. Rotation of forestry enterprise workers is one mechanism used by communities who exploit their forests as a way of equitably distributing opportunities created by forestry, even when it is recognized that this limits professional development.
 Annex 9 Page 3 of 6 6. Cultural values include traditional identification with a number of sacred and cultural heritage sites within the forested areas. In the case of communities with forest management plans, under the revisions to the agrarian reform law made in the late 1980s, communities' cultural sovereignty has been recognized to a greater extent in the country. Expression of this is found in the communal statutes, formal expressions of communal customary laws and traditions. In Oaxaca, communities that have prepared such statutes have included descriptions of their cultural values towards natural resources, descriptions of land tenure boundaries and rights, and descriptions of their management plans for their forest resource base. This can be a valuable record for ensuring that community cultural values are upheld in forest management plans and to formally protect a community's right to allocate resojirces according to the decisions of traditionally selected leaders, rather than those elected through the formal political process or appointed by the government. Key Issues for Project Design 7. Indigenous Cultural Values and Forest Management Forest management plans are designed to promote integrated forest management which is culturally appropriate to local social and cultural values. The studies to be financed under the project will include an integrated approach, including the identification and preservation of cultural sites. Training courses will also include attention to cultural issues in forest management in both courses for the communities and courses for private providers. In the course curriculum designed for scholarship courses to be given to indigenous community members in Oaxaca, this topic will be explored and integrated. 8. Indigenous Institutions and Forestry/Conservation If forestry ejidos and communities are to advance in the levels of control over resource management decisions and efficiency of forestry enterprises, there will need to be considerable trust created in the management of the technical assistance and training component and adequate participation by indigenous leaders and forest managers. There is a strong perception by indigenous groups in Oaxaca that government and some non-governmental organizations providing technical support are paternalistic and undervalue the indigenous world view and cultural system. This is a real barrier to the ability of the project to introduce a forest culture to a significant number of communities. 9. Increases in forest income and efficiency and sophistication of the forestry enterprise also result in significant changes in community life that require a social adaptation. While many communities seek these changes, they also recognize that there will be some painful adjustments required. Training and promotional staff of the project must be aware of this process and seek measures to make the transition easier. It should also be expected that there will be serious resistance to these changes in some communities and that progress towards a highly productive enterprise is unlikely to be without lapses or backtracking. Communities with their own technical service providers have an advantage in that they are more likely to recognize these dynamics and help community leaders to find solutions. Training of non-indigenous, private providers would
 Annex 9 Page 4 of 6 also benefit from modules that make them more aware of and respectful of these dynamics. 10. Land Tenure and Boundary Conflicts The land reform process in Mexico divided agricultural lands into private, ejido, and indigenous community holdings. Ejidos are land reform blocks which include groups of farmers, their individual agricultural parcels, and common grazing and forest lands and residential infrastructure. Communities are extensions of terrain traditionally used by specific indigenous populations, which have their own system of internal government. In 1992, the Government introduced reforms to the Agrarian Law and references to it in Article 27 of the National Constitution. As an incentive for greater investment in ejido lands and to land security, the opportunity was created for ejidos to privatize and request titles to individual parcels or, alternately, to regularize the boundaries of the ejido and of the individual parcels within the ejido. Indigenous communities were given the opportunity to convert to ejidos and indigenous ejidos were given the option of converting to communities. A program of technical assistance for the regularization process for ejidos was created in 1993 called Programa de Certificacion de Derechos Ejidalesy Titulacion de Solares Urbanos (PROCEDE). Under this program, the Procuraduria Agraria initiated a program of legal assistance in cooperation with the other land agencies, the Ministry of Land Reform (SRA), the National Registry (RAN), and the National Statistics and Geographic Institute (INEGI). Overall, the program has been more active in productive agricultural areas and peri-urban areas, than in the more marginal and remote forested areas. 11. PROCEDE has been initiated in the majority of ejidos in Oaxaca. At present, 115 of the ejidos that have entered into the process of regularization are stuck in various stages due to the presence of unresolvable boundary conflicts. There are 350 cases of registered boundary conflicts within ejidos, and between ejidos and communities. Of the 1 17 communities and ejidos for which PROCEDE data exist, 52 percent have some form of conflict and 8 percent lack clear documentation of their land rights (rezago agraria). In most cases boundary conflicts do not affect forest exploitation as management plans simply exclude those areas in conflict. These conflicts only affect forest enterprises should the community seek to access formal credit to capitalize their industry or to enter a joint venture where the bank or investor want land security. 12. In consultations with the land agencies involved in PROCEDE, particularly in dialogues with the anthropologist director of the Ministry of Land Reform, and the director and the staff of the office of the Procuraduria Agraria in Oaxaca, the recommendation has been made that the project include training activities that help forest ejidos and communities with conflicts to resolve them. Given the complicated legal nature of many of the disputes, the PROCEDE agencies have recommended against including any informal conciliation process in the technical assistance component. Instead, they have identified the need for a basic level of training to ejidos and communities which informs them about the process of legal adjudication and provides them with detailed information about the different steps in the process of regularization where conflicts are involved. The
 Annex 9 Page 5 of 6 possibility of extending a pilot training program, which has been tested elsewhere in Mexico, to the state of Oaxaca is being evaluated. Participation in Project Planning and Implementation 13. The project has been designed to address the felt needs of the indigenous forest ejidos and communities in Oaxaca as well as provide a model for expansion to other states with indigenous and non-indigenous community and ejido forest owners. Oaxaca was chosen as a site for the pilot because of the interest of target beneficiaries and state government in forestry development and resource management and because it was the most promising state included in the cases analyzed in the sector review, in terms of the degree of organization of forest ejidos and communities. The project is a technical assistance project which is designed on the premise that there are a significant number of forest ejidos and communities that can take control of the conservation and development of their natural resource base, leading to better resource management and greater generation of income from forestry and conservation activities. The project plans to pilot a series of mechanisms for technical assistance and training that were identified during the sector reviews as beneficial to communal forestry. It is expected that, as technical assistance experience is gained and as community enterprises evolve, communities in Oaxaca will be able to absorb more diverse technical assistance for development of more sophisticated and higher-value forest enterprises. Ejido to Ejido/Community to Community Seminars 14. In FY95, the Bank financed an IDF grant for ejido-to-ejido training by indigenous forest ejidos, which was administered through NAFIN. In two workshops, indigenous forest owners attended courses at two of the more successful ejidos which included modules in which participants outlined development strategies and areas requiring technical assistance and financial support. These workshops were followed by a third evaluation workshop in which participants proposed that regional training networks be established and funds made available to indigenous ejidos and communities for continued training. A second IDF is under preparation which is intended to help the ejidos and communities set up the proposed networks and these regional ejido-to-ejido training methods. The project includes ejido to ejido training within the training component. This activity is planned on a national level, given the strong interest expressed by indigenous ejidos and communities during the first IDF and through other forest networks, and the strong capacity demonstrated by the groups to manage their own training process. SHCP has expressed interest in continuing to channel such resources through NAFIN. Other Training Initiatives 15. In addition to the above-mentioned training, the project would include short and long-term training for ejido and community members. Short term training would attempt to inform a broad base of community members about the range and quality of technical services that they should be able to utilize for forest management plan preparation and
 Annex 9 Page 6 of 6 forest management and extraction decisions. In addition, short-term training would transfer administrative and accounting skills which are key to a community or ejido's ability to manage a forestry enterprise and maximize its returns. Scholarships would be provided for long-term training of community and ejido members in Oaxaca. While it would not be appropriate for the project to finance the development of curricula at the forestry school in Oaxaca, the government is exploring possible development of a curriculum more geared to the needs of the indigenous students. Regional Fora 16. The project will include the development of regional fora in the five or six subregions of the project area. These fora will provide an opportunity for communities to meet collectively to discuss project issues and opportunities, a space for learning about technical assistance and training options, and a space to exchange opinions about the progress of the project and to channel information about their interests and needs to project staff Initially, the promotional unit of the Project Management Unit in SEMARNAP in Oaxaca will request local leaders to call meetings of the regional fora and provide suggestions on agenda topics. With time, it is hoped that these fora will be managed actively by local communities. It is not intended that these provide formal representation of communities and their leaders for forestry issues. It is possible, however, that over time, the communities within the region will begin to develop such formal representation to provide a stronger lobby for regional interests at state level.

doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Community Forestry Project is to support the implementation of key elements in the Government's redefined natural resource management strategy. Specific objectives are to: (1) improve natural resource management and conservation by community and ejido forestry resource owners; and (2) increase the range of forestry-based income generating options available to them. The project will have four components: (1)To assist Oaxaca's communities and ejidos (land grants for legal use and enjoyment that, prior to 1992 constitutional reforms, were state-owned and could not be sold) by financing activities, assistance, and training to prepare and update management plans for timber extraction; to prepare conservation plans for forested areas; to integrate resource management and forestry research; to develop silvicultural skills, and control fire and insects; to understand boundary conflict issues; to access credit, markets, and technologies; to increase the efficiency of forestry activities and enterprises, and to improve business and management, especially financial management skills. (2) To strengthen the capacity of Oaxaca's private service providers to assist communities and ejidos, and finance consultants and equipment needed to review and strengthen the government's certification and evaluation program for private sector providers. (3) To promote non-timber forest products in the six priority states with pine-oak forest by financing studies, grants, salaries, consultants, equipment, materials, and publications. (4) providing finance to strengthen state forestry institutions in five priority states with pine-oak forest.
